title.narrative: Leap4Peace - Colombia

description.narrative: COL-L4P-21-B1

title.narrative: # studies for evidence-based L&A disseminated to political actors
# studies for evidence-based L&A disseminated to political actors

description.narrative: # studies for evidence-based L&A disseminated to political actors
# studies for evidence-based L&A disseminated to political actors

comment.narrative: NIMD has not worked previously with women led CSOs at territorial levels. NIMD’s interest for this first year is to build trust with these actors and consolidate a network of support and work with the purpose of retrieve experiences of their impact on the definition of key elements of the territorial peacebuilding and gender-equity agenda.

NIMD Colombia, in the framework of the global actions of the L4P Consortium, elaborated a paper "Political participation of women in Colombia: advocacy actions from NIMD Colombia's programmes". The purpose of the paper was to make visible the contribution of women to the consolidation of the peace agenda, as well as the current challenges and risks they face in their communities.
This document was accompanied by a video with interviews with different social and political leaders

NIMD Colombia expects to develop and disseminate at least one study for evidence-based L&A per year, for a total of five (5) studies for evidence-based L&A by the end of the project. It is important to note that during 2021, NIMD has advance in one L&A study, but it will only be published until 2022.

title.narrative: International lobby and advocacy for supportive policy
International lobby and advocacy for supportive policy

description.narrative: International lobby and advocacy for supportive international and national policy environments
International lobby and advocacy for supportive international and national policy environments

title.narrative: # of women-led CSOs included in the programme activities

description.narrative: # of women-led CSOs included in the programme activities

comment.narrative:
NIMD has not worked previously with women led CSOs at territorial levels. NIMD’s interest for this first year is to build trust with these actors and consolidate a network of support and work that intends to develop L&A initiatives for territorial implementation of peace projects.
As far as July 31 NIMD conducted a preliminary survey with partner CSOs of national coverage to measure their capacities to mobilize and position women and peace agendas in decision-making scenarios. This survey allows us to develop interventions more tailored to their needs and the expectations of NIMD. 9 actors from national CSOs were surveyed.
This I.O. and indicator was not measured since the target is set to start in 2022

By the end of the year NIMD expects to map territorial and local networks of CSOs and feminist organizations interested in the development of L&A capabilities. NIMD expects to work with at least 2 CSOs at all territorial levels where the program develops interventions.
By the end of the program NIMD expects to include at least 10 women led CSOs in the program activities.

title.narrative: # women-led CSOs with increased L&A capacities

description.narrative: # women-led CSOs with increased L&A capacities

comment.narrative:
NIMD has not worked previously with women led CSOs at territorial levels. NIMD’s interest for this first year is to build trust with these actors and consolidate a network of support and work that intends to develop L&A initiatives for territorial implementation of peace projects.
As far as July 31 NIMD conducted a preliminary survey with partner CSOs of national coverage to measure their capacities to mobilize and position women and peace agendas in decision-making scenarios. This survey allows us to develop interventions more tailored to their needs and the expectations of NIMD.
Among the main results, we find that only 44% of the CSOs work with topics related to gender equality and only 22% with political participation.
On the other hand, even though 100% of them promote spaces for dialogue and 88.8% consider that their advocacy strategies are effective, only 55% claim to have the capacity to mobilize relevant actors in matters of gender equity and peace.
Only 44% of the CSOs surveyed state that they prioritize participation at institutional spaces, which is related to the same percentage claiming to be recognized by institutional actors.
This I.O. and indicator was not measured since the target is set to start in 2022

By the end of the year NIMD expects to map territorial and local networks of CSOs and feminist organizations interested in the development of L&A capabilities.
By the end of the program NIMD expects to increase the capabilities of 8 women led CSOs in the program activities. Considering the survey previously mentioned NIMD will promote CSO’s capacities for them to be able to reach relevant actors to mobilize the agenda of equity and peace. NIMD will also promote L&A strategies so CSOs increment their participation at institutional spaces and get recognition by institutional actors with the purpose to strengthen their collaboration on a joint agenda for women and peace.

comment.narrative: 39 political actors to July 31st, 2021 17 from political parties, 20 from local elected bodies, the Ministry of the Interior and National Electoral Council.

In the 9 dialogue spaces developed by NIMD, the following participated:
Type of actor: 15 political parties, national leadership 18 political parties, local leadership 14 sub-national collegiate bodies

description.narrative: # multi-stakeholder dialogue/platform meetings
# multi-stakeholder dialogue/platform meetings

comment.narrative: NIMD has not worked previously with women leading CSOs at territorial levels. NIMD’s interest for this first year is to build trust with these actors and consolidate a network of support and work with the purpose to reach consensus on the gender equity agenda.
This corresponds to the I.O. 4.2. Women CSOs/Feminist movements develop joint gender-equality agenda and indicator was not measured since the target is set to start in 2022

By the end of the year NIMD aims to map territorial and local networks of CSOs and feminist organizations interested in the consolidation of a joint agenda on gender equity.
NIMD Colombia will develop at least two (2) multi-stakeholder dialogue/platform meetings per year (starting in 2022), for a total of eight (8) multi-stakeholder dialogue/platform meetings by the end of the project

title.narrative: # interparty dialogue meetings
# interparty dialogue meetings

description.narrative: # interparty dialogue meetings
# interparty dialogue meetings

comment.narrative: NIMD is recognized by gender officials of political actors as an impartial actor and leader of safe spaces to promote dialogue on gender equality. This year, NIMD has led, along with local partners, 3 interparty dialogue meetings on the topics: District Multiparty Dialogue for women, National Multiparty Dialogue for women and Multiparty Dialogue of women local councilors.

During 2021, NIMD Colombia, in partnership with the Ministry of the Interior and the District Secretariat for Women, carried out 9 spaces for multi-party dialogue, broken down as follows:
- 1 Multiparty Women's Roundtable at the national level. - 3 multi-party women's roundtables at the regional level (1 in the city of Medellín, Antioquia, and 2 in the city of Popayán, Cauca). - 3: Multi-party women's roundtables at district level in Bogotá. - 2 district meetings of women councillors in the city of Bogotá

NIMD will take advantage of the recognition and trust gained with political actors to develop 2 more interparty dialogue meetings on the second half of 2021 on the following topics: violence against women in politics, PAU principles (parity, alternance, universality), among others. Furthermore, will start the inception phase for rolling out innovative dialogue approaches based on the principles of the deliberative democracy and design thinking.

title.narrative: # political actors who adopt measures and policies to enhance representation of women in their decision-making processes
# political actors who adopt measures and policies to enhance representation of women in their decision-making processes

description.narrative: # political actors who adopt measures and policies to enhance representation of women in their decision-making processes
# political actors who adopt measures and policies to enhance representation of women in their decision-making processes

comment.narrative:
2 institutional political actors adopted internal measures to ensure gender equality.
1. The Partido de la U requested technical assistance from NIMD Colombia to update its statutes. NIMD made recommendations to incorporate measures in favour of the political participation of women and the LGBTI population.
2. Alianza Verde Party, requested technical assistance from NIMD Colombia for the revision of its protocol on gender-based violence and violence against women in politics. NIMD Colombia made suggestions to strengthen the action route and immediate reparation measures for women victims.
1 political party (PSUN) with adopted gender equality measures from the development of GRIPP strategy, to December 31st, 2021

comment.narrative: NIMD has not worked previously with women led CSOs at territorial levels. NIMD’s interest for this first year is to build trust with these actors and consolidate a network of support and work that intends to mobilize L&A initiatives for territorial implementation of peace projects.
This I.O. and indicator was not measured since the target is set for 2025

By the end of the year NIMD aims to map territorial and local networks of CSOs and feminist organizations interested in the consolidation of L&A initiatives for the peace-building agenda. By the end of the project, NIMD Colombia will promote at least two high impact national advocacy initiatives.

title.narrative: Supportive policy environment for women’s participation
Supportive policy environment for women’s participation

description.narrative:
Supportive policy environment for women’s rights and political participation in peacebuilding (LTO2)
Programme contribute to this LTO by working through 2 pathways:
Pathway 3: Collaboration for better policies and Pathway 4: Lobbying & Advocacy (L&A) for implementation of UNSCR 1325 and SDG 5
Pathway 3: Collaboration for better policies
For women to participate meaningfully to sustaining peace, the policy environment must support, respect and protect their rights, participation and representation. In Burundi, Colombia and Myanmar, existing post-conflict legislative frameworks already provide some guarantee of women’s participation, on paper. However, implementation lags behind. Mutual trust and dialogue are necessary ingredients in order to put these frameworks into practice, and to improve them based on international best practice. For this to materialize, political actors need to agree on minimum criteria and benchmarks, and collectively move forward on these issues.
The Intermediate Outcomes (IOs) in this pathway, which contribute to LTO2 are: Political parties develop joint gender-equality agendas (IO.3.1) Political actors jointly advocate for the implementation of gender-equality legislation (IO.3.2) Political actors collaborate for better policies (IO.3.3)
The programme aims to achieve these outcomes through the following set of intervention strategies:
Interparty dialogue platforms/women caucuses Existing dialogue platforms in all three countries will facilitate the development of interparty agendas on women’s participation in political and peace-making processes. INSPIRED-method based multi-stakeholder dialogue Through the INSPIRED methodology NIMD facilitates multi-stakeholder dialogue between civil society and political actors in emerging democracies and post-conflict settings. Peer learning and knowledge exchange across countries Exposure of key duty-bearers and political actors to environments with good practices related to women’s rights and inclusion is a proven way to enhance understanding of, and openness to, changes in domestic policy on gender issues.
Pathway 4: Lobbying & Advocacy (L&A) for implementation of UNSCR 1325 and SDG 5
At a time when the civic space to advocate towards governments is rapidly shrinking, CSOs must work together and push back against this trend in a concerted lobbying and advocacy effort. The Consortium will, therefore, engage in mutual capacity strengthening, and align with like-minded women’s organizations and CSOs in all three countries. The exact nature of the CSOs’ lobby agendas will depend on the country context and available civic space.
Strengthening CSOs’ capacities is a pivotal enabler to reach LT02. While in-country CSO alliances can function as important pressure points to change incentive structures, political actors need to take the agendas of CSOs into account and reflect them in policy and practice. Therefore, LEAP4Peace will also engage with political actors to stimulate their commitment to the WPS agenda. Advocacy initiatives can help put positive pressure on national decisionmakers, by connecting local- and national-level actors to international feminist agendas, regional and international bodies, and women’s rights networks. Therefore, the Consortium will use its existing outreach and networks to promote women’s participation in peacebuilding. This outreach is based on both the experience in three countries in the programme, and on international good practice and experience of Consortium Partners. This Pathway aligns closely to the international frameworks and agreements around National Action Plans and the fulfilment of UNSCR 1325, and SDG 5.
The Intermediate Outcomes (IOs) in this pathway, which contribute to LTO2 are: Strengthened like-minded CSOs align for joint advocacy agenda (IO.4.1) CSOs effectively monitor and lobby for policy change and implementation (IO.4.2) International lobby and advocacy for supportive international and national policy environments (IO.4.3)
And the intervention strategies are: CSO capacity-building assessment and strategy We will build on our existing monitoring and evaluation tool that measures CSO performance, based on the Five Capabilities model, and enables them to acknowledge their strengths and weaknesses, and implement strategies for capacity improvement. The ‘10 Steps’ and ‘Beyond Consultation’ L&A tools These GAPS tools helps governments and duty-bearers to get commitments on WPS and put them into action. Gender Policy Analysis tool This tool, developed by GEN, analyses legal and policy documents in Myanmar and compares them against international gender standards. This tool will be used also in the other countries.

title.narrative: # of laws blocked, proposed, adopted or improved to promote women’s voice, agency, leadership, and representative participation in (political) decision-making processes in conflict prevention, peace- and state-building

description.narrative: # of laws blocked, proposed, adopted or improved to promote women’s voice, agency, leadership, and representative participation in (political) decision-making processes in conflict prevention, peace- and state-building

comment.narrative: Bill 042/2 Women’s campaign financing - Bill 409/20 Violence against women in politics -Law 2148/21 on Maternity leave for women deputies and local councilwomen 3 to July 31st, 2021. Only 1 of them, the one on violence against women in politics-VAWP, had NIMD’s assistance through participation at public hearings and technical support on the texts adopted at the Congress.

By December 2025, NIMD will present or improve two laws to promote women’s voice, agency, and topics such as fight against VAWP, parity, leadership, and representative participation in (political) decision-making processes on conflict prevention

comment.narrative: By December 2025, through the Observatory of Violence against women in politics NIMD will develop technical assistance and Lobby & Advocacy initiatives to advance in instruments to prevent and mitigate this phenomenon. This will be the policy promoted by NIMD jointly built with political actors.

title.narrative: Women are represented in peacebuilding decision-making
Women are represented in peacebuilding decision-making

description.narrative:
Women are represented in decision-making roles for peacebuilding (LTO1)
Programme contribute to this LTO by working through 2 pathways:
Pathway 1: Women’s empowerment for political leadership and Pathway 2: Creating space for women’s participation
Pathway 1: Women’s empowerment for political leadership Women must be involved at each stage of the peacebuilding process. While presence at the negotiation table is vital, involvement in the design, implementation and follow-up of peace agreements and settlements is equally important. If women are to influence the direction of post-conflict re-building and policymaking, we need a critical mass of capable and representative women political leaders, active in both political institutions and overall political and public life.
This long-term outcome targets women directly by building their capacity, reinforcing women’s agency, and strengthening their networks. By strengthening and building existing skills, and by engaging men as ambassadors for women’s political participation, the foundation is laid for an increased role of women in peacebuilding and politics.
The programme’s Intermediate Outcomes (IO) along pathway 1, which contribute to LTO1, are: - Women’s caucuses and networks are strengthened; - Women nominate themselves for decision-making positions; - Male and female (aspiring) politicians work as allies to enhance women’s participation.
The programme aims to achieve these outcomes through the following set of intervention strategies: Democracy education: Female Leadership Academy We will build on the existing experience, reputation and infrastructure of Democracy Schools in the three programme countries, and integrate a Female Leadership Academy. We will rollout and adopt specific curricula on gender-equality and conflict-sensitivity teaching methods. Mentoring and networking The programme will support knowledge transfer and peer support through women’s networks and caucuses, and motivate women to run for decision-making positions. We will support (aspiring) women leaders to become (political) focal points within their communities, and advance their position in peacebuilding processes. Engaging men We will work with male allies at all levels; support them to understand social barriers; and empower them to enhance women’s rights and political participation.
Pathway 2: Creating space for women’s participation
Empowering women is a significant step, but it is not enough. Women also need to operate in a conducive space in order to participate fully, apply their skills, and voice their rights and needs. Therefore, it is vital to work with political actors to not only enable the representation of (the interests of) women in political and peacebuilding agendas or processes, but also to directly facilitate the participation of women in leadership positions within political decision-making organizations.
Despite the important role political actors play in peacebuilding, they often receive little international support or attention. Engaging with political actors is often perceived as a threat to impartiality for international or multilateral organizations or donors. The key to creating space within the internal structures of political organizations is to have the political actors reinforce and institutionalize women’s leadership and political participation themselves. By addressing and removing internal barriers for women, space is created for more diverse political organizations.
The Intermediate Outcomes (IOs) along pathway 2, which contribute to LTO1 are: - Political actors develop internal gender-equality plans; - Political actors implement internal gender-equality regulations; - Executive leadership integrates and supports women’s participation internally.
The programme aims to achieve these through the following set of intervention strategies:
Gender Roadmap for Inclusive Political Parties (GRIP) NIMD developed the GRIP Methodology based on its Women Political Rights (WPR) Programme (2014- 2017, financed by the Dutch MFA). The GRIPP is a method for political parties to become aware of any barriers that limit women’s participation within their own party, and offers ways to overcome these barriers. The GRIP offers five steps for parties to:  engage party cadres in self-assessment of the inclusiveness of internal procedures;  promote ownership of the resulting analysis and addressing the identified barriers;  provide executive leadership with a structured pathway to overcome barriers.
(Social) media campaigns We will collaborate with (social) media organizations to raise awareness of women’s leadership, overcome gender stereotypes and promote an inclusive democratic culture. This will be done in collaboration with women politicians. This is because the use of social media for online abuse and violence is often targeted at women politicians
Support to women’s wings We support the capacity and influencing role of party’s women’s wings so they can mainstream a gender-equality perspective into (internal) policy development.

Women are represented in decision-making roles for peacebuilding (LTO1)
Programme contribute to this LTO by working through 2 pathways:

title.narrative: Women’s satisfaction with participation in political and peacebuilding processes (disaggregated by age/intersectional group)

description.narrative: Women’s satisfaction with participation in political and peacebuilding processes (disaggregated by age/intersectional group)
Women’s satisfaction with participation in political and peacebuilding processes (disaggregated by age/intersectional group)

comment.narrative: By July 2021, 14,15% (15 women) of NIMD’s female beneficiaries were satisfied with their participation in political and peacebuilding processes.
By December 2025, NIMD expects to increase its women beneficiaries’ satisfaction up to 30% through capacity development for them to take place on decision making scenarios

title.narrative: Women nominate themselves for decision-making positions
Women nominate themselves for decision-making positions

description.narrative: Women nominate themselves for decision-making positions
Women nominate themselves for decision-making positions

title.narrative: Share of women candidates
Share of women candidates

description.narrative: Share of women candidates
Share of women candidates

comment.narrative: 71 women manifest their interest to participate as candidates in election scenarios, 26 at municipal councils, 15 at Local Councils (JAL) and 8 at Youth Municipal Councils, 4 at Mayorships, and 7 Departmental Assemblies, 5 at National Congress

This corresponds to the I.O. 1.2. and the correct indicator is # Of women who partake in NIMD trainings that are willing to candidate themselves for decision-making positions.
During 2021, 50 women participants in the different training processes developed by NIMD expressed their interest in running for elected office: - 13 to the Senate of the Republic - 7 for the House of Representatives - 2 for Mayor's Office - 3 for Departmental Assemblies - 14 for Municipal Councils - 7 to Municipal Youth Councils - 4 to Local Action Boards
NIMD will strengthen 8 women's capacities to partake in politics through trainings, for them to nominate themselves at Youth Municipal Councils as they will be elected this year.

title.narrative: # women (aspiring) leaders trained
# women (aspiring) leaders trained

description.narrative: # women (aspiring) leaders trained
# women (aspiring) leaders trained

comment.narrative: Up to July 31st, 134 aspiring female leaders have been trained by NIMD since L4P Programme started

893 political and civic women participated in the following NIMD training processes: 1. 8 Democracy Schools, under its "School of Dialogue Innovation and Leadership" model in the departments of La Guajira, Cesar, Cordoba, Cauca, Cauca, Tolima, Caqueta and Valle del Cauca. A total of 257 women participated in these processes, 82 of whom were young women.
2. Empowerment Schools: Aimed exclusively at emerging civic and political leaders. Three schools were implemented in alliance with three territorial entities (Government of Valle del Cauca, Government of Bolivar and Mayor's Office of Cota) in which 98 women participated, of which 32 were young women.
3. Schools and training for political parties: (Partido Social de Unidad Nacional - Partido de la U, Partido Cambio Radical and Partido Polo Democrático Alternativo) carried out 3 training initiatives for their militants and potential candidates, through which 113 women were trained, of which 24 were young women.
4. Training for other relevant actors: NIMD Colombia in alliance with Ministry of Interior, Occupy Politics and ARN trained 425 women, of which 222 were young women.
Of these 839 women trained 102 said they were:
- Afro-descendants: 52 - LGBTQ+: 6 - Indigenous: 16 - Displaced: 2 - Disabled: 2 - Victims: 24
The election of Municipal Youth Councils allowed us to far surpass the target set for 2021.
150 aspiring female leaders trained by December 31st, 2021.

title.narrative: # democracy school graduates
# democracy school graduates

description.narrative: # democracy school graduates
# democracy school graduates

comment.narrative: NIMD Colombia in the framework of its training processes graduated 238 discriminated women as follows: Democracy Schools: 129 women received graduation certificates in the schools of Cesar, Cordoba, La Guajira. 2. 2. Empowerment Schools: 98. 3. School for political parties: 11 women from the Polo Democrático Alternativo Party received graduation certificates in 2021.

By December 2021, NIMD will have implemented 3 Democracy Schools in three of the most conflict-affected territories, half of the beneficiaries are women. 72 Democracy Schools graduates to December 31st, 2021.
